Award.AwardTitle: Turnover Dynamics in Two Patch-Tracking Sympatric Rail Metapopulations: Validating Inferences from Occupancy Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study examines differing patterns of population colonization and extinction exhibited by the threatened black rail and the non-threatened Virginia rail inhabiting the same set of wetlands. These two cryptic marsh birds have similar natural histories, but may differ greatly in their ability to fly to new sites based on relationships derived from presence-absence surveys. This study will answer two main questions: Do the patterns of colonization implied from presence-absence data correspond to dispersal behavior? Are the correlates of population turnover the same when the proportion of sites occupied remains constant as when occupancy is increasing or declining? By surveying numerous small wetlands in the Sierra Foothills of California, this research will: compare dispersal distances estimated from turnover to direct measures from telemetry and genetic structure; track colonization of patches after recent extinction events caused by West Nile virus; determine the origin of colonists using genetic and isotope measures to untangle the contributions of short- and long-distance dispersal; and monitor for reoccurrence of West Nile virus by testing blood of all captured rails.

A broader impact resulting from this research will be the development of techniques for working with landowners to support conservation of rare species on their land. Private land supports a disproportionate percentage of endangered species and controversies concerning the protection of species under the Endangered Species Act occur. Few field studies are conducted on private property. This study provides a unique opportunity to explore ways of working with private landowners, and for educational outreach through a variety of approaches. The project will integrate research and education by training graduate and undergraduate students, and by offering local landowners, Audubon volunteers, high school students and teachers the chance to experience research in the field with researchers. Results from this project will advance Black Rail conservation by producing important data on dispersal ability and connectivity among regional populations, and informing management of wetlands created specifically for black rails in one of the most rapidly growing regions of California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined the patterns of colonization and extinction exhibited by the threatened Black Rail and the nonthreatened Virginia Rail inhabiting the same set of wetlands in the Sierra Nevada foothills of California.  These two secretive marsh birds are rarely ever observed.  They have similar natural histories, but appear to differ greatly in their ability to fly to new sites, based on the relationship between colonization of unoccupied sites derived from surveys deigned to detect the presence or absence of rails and their isolation.  Rails of both species disappeared from many wetland sites after West Nile Virus arrived in the study region in 2007.

This study intend answered two main questions: (1) Do the patterns of colonization implied from presence-absence data from surveys correspond to dispersal behavior?; and (2) What is the origin of the individuals that colonize unoccupied sites?  To answer these questions, we monitored for the occurrence of rails at about 250 wetlands in Butte, Nevada and Yuba counties.  We also captured 336 Black Rails and 98 Virginia Rails in the Sierra foothills and San Francisco Bay.  We took blood and feather samples to conduct genetic and isotopic analyses in order to untangle the contributions of short- and long-distance dispersal to colonization.  We used genetic tests to identify parents and offspring; the distance between them provided a direct measure of dispersal within the Sierra foothills.  We used genetic tests in conjunction with stable isotope analysis to quantify long distance dispersal between the foothills and San Francisco Bay.

California’s historic drought from 2013 through fall 2015 dried many wetlands, which further reduced the proportion of wetlands that were occupied by Black and Virginia Rails.  The proportion of sites occupied by Black Rails in 2015 had declined to ~20% from roughly 60% occupancy in 2006.  A similar trend occurred for Virginia Rails but the decline began in 2012, well after West Nile Virus arrived, and may be more driven by dry conditions.

For Black Rails, we found good agreement between the average dispersal distance between 23 pairs of parents and offspring determined from the genetic tests (5.6 ± 1.9 km) and the dispersal distance estimated from the relationship between colonization and two measures of isolation (7.5 and 5.5 km).  

For the more vagile Virginia Rail, however, few parent-offspring pairs were found and colonization was not strongly related to isolation, making it difficult to identify a scale with the best fit.  Both results suggesting frequent dispersal outside of the 2000 km2 study area.

Stable isotope analysis and genetic analysis revealed that most Black Rails (334 of 336 or 99%) were residents of their capture populations.  Two migrants were identified that may have moved greater than 100 km in the year before capture.  Seven other individuals were identified as migrants to the foothills based only on their isotopic values.  However, mapping of isotope values from wetland soils revealed high variation across tens of meters within the area of the foothills where these birds were found, suggesting they are not likely to represent long-distance dispersal events.

Among the broader impacts resulting from the activities are: (1) Developing techniques for working with landowners to support conservation of rare species on their land.  Private land supports a disproportionate percentage of endangered species and controversies concerning the protection of species under the Endangered Species Act occur.  Few field studies are conducted on private property.  Since 60% of the wetlands we visit are on private land, this study provided a unique opportunity to explore ways of working with private landowners, and for educational outreach through a variety of approaches.  We communicated frequently with landowners using newsletters and telephone calls; (2) We assisted the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in the development of Black Rail conservation plans using the occupancy data gathered in this study.  Our work has also influenced California Fish and Wildlife Commission's conservation strategies and the management of their wildlife management areas for rails.  Presentations were given for the general public and state and federal agencies, and newsletters written for cooperating landowners; and (3) Integration of research and education by supporting the Ph.D. studies of three UC Berkeley students, who were being trained in field ecology, modeling and lab (molecular and isotope) methods, 11 undergraduate students who collected data and produced two honors theses, and about a dozen postgraduate researchers, who were trained in field ecology and ornithology.
